content.raw:
Yeah, in general I strongly discourage `using namespace X` anywhere, even inside of translation units, because it can create unresolvable ambiguity with the global namespace. I made an exception here because it’s an integration test for this library, so there isn’t much risk of collisions with symbols from other libraries.

But it’s also confusing for humans to read, so I’m very open to tweaking the style here.
content.html:
Yeah, in general I strongly discourage using namespace X anywhere, even inside of translation units, because it can create unresolvable ambiguity with the global namespace. I made an exception here because it’s an integration test for this library, so there isn’t much risk of collisions with symbols from other libraries.

But it’s also confusing for humans to read, so I’m very open to tweaking the style here.

AngularVectorType and LinearVectorType are both defined with a using X = Y declaration. If you have something like

using A = C;
using B = C;

then A and B are considered equivalent symbols. Once compilation has finished, any instance of A or B will be replaced with C.

An unfortunate side-effect of this is it offers less type protection. A user could pass in a Linear Vector quantity into an argument that expects an Angular Vector quantity. I’d be open to tweaking the implementation so that these two types are treated as unique symbols by the compiler, but that’s not something we necessarily need to decide right now. We could change that in the future without significantly impacting the API.

update.description:
This PR introduces an implementation of Frame Semantics, as described in the design docs. It builds directly off of the [Feature System PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/24).

The concept and implementation follows the [design doc](https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/659926/Ignition+Physics) pretty closely, so I suggest looking there for an exhaustive explanation. But here is a high-level outline of what we have:

* Quantities \(e.g. vectors, points, poses\) that have a frame of reference are given by a `FramedQuantity<>`. `FramedQuantity<>` is a class template that allows any kind of mathematical quantity to be framed \(assuming it makes mathematical sense for the quantity to be framed\). It uses the [policy-based design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy-based_design) pattern to determine how to transform various quantities between reference frames.
* Frames are identified by a FrameID. The FrameID is very similar to the Identity class which is used by the Feature System, except FrameIDs are only available for entities that are considered frames by their physics plugin.
* FramedQuantities and Frames are templated on their dimensionality and precision. This allows us to simultaneously support 2D/3D spaces and float/double precision with all the same API and implementation \(note: fixed precision has not been tested yet, but should be possible in theory\). However, to make this possible, the implementation is using the Eigen C\+\+ library instead of ignition-math for its underlying data types.
* Physics plugins can decide whether they support expressing Models, Links, and/or Joints as frames \(e.g. a plugin can decide that it considers Models and Links to be frames, but not Joints\). The physics engine only needs to be able to return the transform of a frame with respect to the world, and the Frame Semantics implementation will take care of the rest.
* FramedQuantities can be “resolved” with respect to any reference frame. This means that there is a very simple API which will give you the raw quantity of a FramedQuantity as it would be expressed with respect to any arbitrary frame of your choosing. 

‌
update.title: Frame Semantics

content.raw: The `::FrameData` and `::RelativeFrameData` namespacing was confusing to me, since it looks like these are in the global scope, but I guess it works because of the `using` statements at the top of this file?
content.html: The ::FrameData and ::RelativeFrameData namespacing was confusing to me, since it looks like these are in the global scope, but I guess it works because of the using statements at the top of this file?

content.raw: could we add `"angular acceleration"` as the final argument?
content.html: could we add "angular acceleration" as the final argument?

content.raw: an example of this would be linear_velocity = angular_velocity x position
content.html: an example of this would be linear_velocity = angular_velocity x position

content.raw: an example of this would be: torque = position x force
content.html: an example of this would be: torque = position x force

content.raw: I get that they are all the same size in 3d, but I'm just checking that the compiler will be fine with interchanging them
content.html: I get that they are all the same size in 3d, but I'm just checking that the compiler will be fine with interchanging them

content.raw: You've listed these 4 permutations, but why don't we need four versions of the `Cross` function with different arguments?
content.html: You've listed these 4 permutations, but why don't we need four versions of the Cross function with different arguments?

content.raw: Yep, that’s out of date. We’re supporting 2D already.
content.html: Yep, that’s out of date. We’re supporting 2D already.

content.raw: is this comment out of date? It seems like some of the `CoordinateSpace` types are using the `size_t` template parameter
content.html: is this comment out of date? It seems like some of the CoordinateSpace types are using the size_t template parameter

content.raw: spell out SE == Special Euclidean group
it could be helpful for people googling what SO(3) means to spell out that SO stands for Special Orthogonal group
content.html: it could be helpful for people googling what SO(3) means to spell out that SO stands for Special Orthogonal group

content.raw:
It could still be used for `ign-math` classes because it's not tied to Eigen, but admittedly I haven't made any attempt to use it with `ign-math` data types because they lack a template parameter for dimensionality, which is really nice to have.

Changing the wording here would be a good thing to do regardless.
content.html:
It could still be used for ign-math classes because it's not tied to Eigen, but admittedly I haven't made any attempt to use it with ign-math data types because they lack a template parameter for dimensionality, which is really nice to have.

Changing the wording here would be a good thing to do regardless.

content.raw: I think not `native ign-math classes` anymore?
